channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia Grants Snowden 1-Year Asylum
item.description: The refugee status in Russia was the first formal support from another government for Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor wanted for leaking details of surveillance programs.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Assocoated Press Television, via Associated Press
item.media:description: This image taken from television shows Anatoly Kucherena, a Russian lawyer assisting Edward J. Snowden, showing Mr. Snowden's temporary refugee status document.

item.title: Japan’s Finance Minister Retracts Statement on Nazis
item.description: The official, Taro Aso, said his remarks were taken out of context and that his hope had been to provoke a calm debate of whether to change the country’s pacifist Constitution.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: India Ink: Life in India’s Juvenile Homes
item.description: Experts and former inmates weigh in on the flaws of the Indian juvenile justice system.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA
item.media:description: Policemen in plain clothes escorting the juvenile accused, center, in the Dec. 16 gang rape, in New Delhi on July 11.

item.title: Spain’s Leader Rejects Calls for His Resignation
item.description: During a rare appearance before lawmakers Thursday morning, Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy admitted errors but denied widespread corruption in his governing party.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: Egypt Warns Morsi Supporters to End Protests
item.description: An Interior Ministry spokesman appealed to the protesters to “give priority to the interest of the homeland, to comply with the public interest and to quickly leave and evacuate.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: Ruling on Berlusconi Case by Italy’s Top Court Is Expected
item.description: Italy’s highest court was expected to rule on Thursday afternoon on a closely watched tax fraud case that could end the political career of Silvio Berlusconi.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO

item.title: Greece May Face Gap of 11 Billion Euros, I.M.F. Says
item.description: The shortfall may require Greece’s European creditors to consider giving it debt relief and more money to meet the requirements of its bailout, the Fund said.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Kerry, in Pakistan Visit, Sees Longer U.S. Role in Afghanistan
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said on Thursday that he expected the United States and Afghanistan to complete a security agreement allowing American forces to stay in the country after 2014.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Challenger in Zimbabwe Calls for Investigation Into Election
item.description: Morgan Tsvangarai, the challenger to Zimbabwe’s longtime president, Robert Mugabe, called the country’s election a “huge farce.”
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Morgan Tsvangirai called Zimbabwe's election a “huge farce” on Thursday.

item.title: Court Rules North Koreans Can Inherit Property From South
item.description: The verdict opens the way for what could be a flood of lawsuits involving families separated after the Korean War sealed the border between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Afghans Yield in Dispute With U.S. Over Stiff Fines for Cargo Shipments
item.description: Under the threat of losing hundreds of millions of dollars in American aid, Afghan officials backed down in an argument that had threatened to drive up the cost of the Western military withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: India Ink: How Not to Talk About Poverty in India
item.description: The callous lexicon India’s politicians deploy to describe the challenge of poverty.
item.dc:creator: By MONOBINA GUPTA
item.media:description: Children eating food at a roadside temporary shelter in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, on Oct. 3, 2011.

item.title: China Reports Increase in Manufacturing
item.description: The manufacturing index, provided by the Chinese authorities, indicated that recent small-scale economic support measures in Beijing might be having some effect on demand.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,241 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Police in Turkey Act to Halt a Protest
item.description: The police in Istanbul fired tear gas to disperse several hundred people protesting the police crackdown on antigovernment demonstrators earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil President Offers Measure to Try to Untangle Bus Traffic
item.description: President Dilma Rousseff announced Wednesday that the federal government would set aside $1.3 billion to improve bus service in São Paulo.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Missing Banker in Kazakhstan Accused of Fraud Is Arrested in Southern France
item.description: Mukhtar Ablyazov, a Kazakh businessman accused of embezzling $6 billion from BTA, a bank he once controlled, has been arrested near Cannes in southern France, a police official said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: U.N. Team in Syria Is Set to Investigate Accusations of Chemical Attacks
item.description: United Nations officials said experts from the organization would go to Syria as soon as possible to investigate three clashes in which chemical weapons are suspected of having been used.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: A Modest Decline of Homicides in Mexico
item.description: Violence caused by the drug war in Mexico may be abating, making it the first decline in six years, according to figures released by the government this week.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: At War Blog: Dog of War Pays Ultimate Sacrifice for Soldier
item.description: A Navy dog handler, after a blast that sent him flying into the air and left him wounded, finds that his canine partner bore the brunt of the explosion and protected him from more serious injury.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ELLIOTT GARBER
item.media:description: Master-at-Arms First Class Leroy Williams Jr. and Dinomt, a bomb-sniffing dog, in Afghanistan in 2012.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Abortion Bill Becomes Law in Ireland
item.description: President Michael D. Higgins has signed into law a bill legalizing abortion, though only in exceptional cases where doctors deem a woman’s life is at risk.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Lede: Stunning Images of Destroyed Syrian City
item.description: Reporters have been left searching for words as images emerge of vast tracts of ruins where, until recently, the vibrant residential neighborhood of Khalidiya stood in the country’s third-largest city, Homs.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Syrian government forces patrolled the Khalidiya neighborhood of Homs on Sunday.

item.title: Sending Message to Iran, House Approves Tougher Sanctions
item.description: The House overwhelmingly approved legislation on Wednesday that would impose the toughest sanctions yet on Iran, calling the measure a critical step to cripple the country’s disputed nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Lawmakers in Uruguay Vote to Legalize Marijuana
item.description: Legislators approved the bill, opening the way for the authorities to create one of Latin America’s most ambitious nationwide endeavors in overhauling drug policy.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Rome Journal: Road Through Roman History Creates Colossal Headache
item.description: A plan to ban private vehicles on Via dei Fori Imperiali, a wide, busy artery that passes the Colosseum, has pitted the mayor and conservationists against residents and shops.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Via dei Fori Imperiali is a wide, busy artery that passes the Colosseum.
